posts.title: Tools for Action
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[["embed",{"url":"https://twitter.com/theflowingsky/status/1332020417410834433?s=21","html":"

this is why product designers need an IDE, not a drawing tool

600+ variants?? and the mechanic for creating them is…editing each one by hand???

the sheer lack of imagination in design tooling astounds me https://t.co/3MdPMNxQFs

— devin // (@theflowingsky) November 26, 2020
","type":"rich","metadata":{"url":"https://twitter.com/theflowingsky/status/1332020417410834433","author_name":"devin //","author_url":"https://twitter.com/theflowingsky","width":550,"height":null,"cache_age":"3153600000","provider_name":"Twitter","provider_url":"http://www.twitter.com/","version":"1.0"},"caption":"A tweet capturing the essence of why product designers need an IDE"}],["embed",{"url":"https://twitter.com/dylan_steck/status/1342197974328340486?s=21","html":"

I have been thinking a lot lately about how the future of education could be created with SRS and an explorable graph of data that anyone can publish to, but is verified with strict standards. Great to see the core idea being built out https://t.co/nE3ZbTW1PO

— Dylan Steck (@Dylan_Steck) December 24, 2020
","type":"rich","metadata":{"url":"https://twitter.com/Dylan_Steck/status/1342197974328340486","author_name":"Dylan Steck","author_url":"https://twitter.com/Dylan_Steck","width":550,"height":null,"cache_age":"3153600000","provider_name":"Twitter","provider_url":"http://www.twitter.com/","version":"1.0"},"caption":"Imagine Wikipedia as a graph of Linked Data!"}],["image",{"src":"/content/images/2020/12/berry_adas.png","width":700,"height":451,"caption":"A visualization of berrypicking (source)","cardWidth":""}]],"markups":[["strong"]],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Knowledge management and tools for thought have become buzzworthy topics in the tech industry, notably with the rise of Roam Research, the note-taking tool for thought, and the concurrent rise of #roamcult on Twitter. Productivity and personal development have been topics of fascination by the most advanced technologists, yet the community of knowledge management and tools for thought enthusiasts never found a home nor a true voice until the rise of Roam. The community races to build extensions for Roam despite the lack of a public API, engages in lengthy Twitter threads with the product's founder and evangelist, Conor White-Sullivan, about the product's features, and shares organizational hacks. In the process, Conor has taught users about the efficacy of certain note-taking methods in Roam, with some yielding high output from users that need it the most(eg. those who deal with the most knowledge and have the most difficult time organizing it). As the community focuses mostly on the upkeep involved in organizing a Roam graph or a Notion page, I offer a glimpse into the future of thought work. What if we managed work activity in the same way we so finely maintain our Roam graphs?"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"For those who might not be familiar, here's how Roam works in a nutshell: Roam is a note-taking app that helps users organize and contextualize knowledge. Users create bidirectional links for each named entity("real world" objects, such as places, people, ideas, or events) in their notes, so they can see every reference to a named entity, as well as the context within which it was referenced. Roam features a toolbelt of advanced commands to manipulate text the same way a statistician would master functions in Microsoft Excel. For example, a user can filter specific references to a named entity, embed code blocks and images into notes, embed references to text snippets between different notes, and even learn notes with spaced repetition."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Users who become fully invested in organizing their knowledge and spend lots of time working with loads of data tend to get the most out of Roam. In particular, the Zettlekasten note-taking method has been popularized by #roamcult, which emphasizes constant note-taking to enlarge the number of connections between concepts and help one build knowledge. This system requires a lot of hands-on work but has helped many, especially knowledge workers, organize their work. It has also emphasized writing as an important part of the creative process for any discipline, especially product design, one that is so subjective."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"While a tool for thought(namely Roam) helps produce a rich graph of contextualized notes and(if properly followed) can help users produce better ideas/learn more, notes generally aren't the only part of a user's workflow, even if the user is a knowledge worker, simply because of how many steps and applications typical workflows require. Even if a knowledge worker's only other app interaction is searching Google, a database, or a website, a knowledge worker still makes multiple decisions and inquiries that lead them to either augment the search query, read a particular website/data entry/article, or click a link. This non-linear search process called berrypicking is one that most people follow as they search the web, but is one that is highly utilized by knowledge workers, who surface multiple sources, search results, and webpages to collect the context necessary to augment the search query, find the right results, or come to certain conclusions/form certain hypotheses."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"And yes, it's important to focus on the learning process and understanding that the knowledge worker must make their interpretations of the information they are presented. However, a knowledge worker could be much more productive and make better use of contextualized information if they had a language to organize the rest of their workflow with the same degree of specificity and the same access to context as in Roam. Other professions have advanced tools that they use to do their work and track their progress(insert examples), so why can't knowledge workers?"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Here are a few examples of tools that can be crafted for creatives to help them experience the quantum leaps in their productivity, creativity, and cognition as they work, the same way Roam has for knowledge workers:"]]],[3,"ol",[[[0,[],0,"An advanced editing tool for interface and interaction designers"]]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Other creative disciplines have advanced software they can use. Knowledge workers can use Roam, a software engineer can use an IDE, a video editor can use advanced editing software, a music producer can use a DAW, the list goes on and on. All of these tools have steep learning curves but offer rich languages for building creative material and, over time, creatives experience exponential increases in their productivity, just as one sees exponential increases in memory as they expand their Roam graph and their usage of the spaced repetition system. Interface designers, however, are stuck to vector-based software programs, such as Figma, Sketch, and Adobe Illustrator/Photoshop/XD. While these programs are easy to use and allow designers to streamline certain parts of their workflow, motion design features are limited, as are design system features, which seem too primitive and assume that a feature has to be implemented a certain way regardless of the context, which doesn't offer much room for exploration. Some tools, such as Framer and Facebook Origami, attempt to create languages to prototype interactions or further customize interface designs, but overall, designers are stuck using primitive vector-based systems that enforce a very "static" style of design and make it harder to use design software as a legitimate tool in a project or its tech stack, or just help the designer best express themself."]]],[10,0],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"2. Online databases and berrypicking"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"A knowledge worker might spend a lot of time in Roam and Notion organizing their notes and trying to learn it, but for anyone who is working with content, or in some other way, there is other work and thinking done outside of Roam that users can't properly organize or record. Take the way people search, for example. When search engines like Google first became popular twenty years ago, most users would follow classic information retrieval models that were set by the search engines, where a user would search for something, click on their result, do what they have to do, and then close their browser or move on to the next task. Nowadays, most people who search the web, especially creatives and tech geeks, follow an information retrieval pattern called berrypicking(insert Focus image), where researchers make certain discoveries or inquiries as they search(or browse a database) which they then use to augment the query, change their notes, do something in their work software, etc. It's these moments that contain the true source of our inspiration and provides the real context."]]],[10,1],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"For the past three years, I have been researching knowledge management, mostly within the frame of desktop organization and productivity in the workflow of many SaaS apps. I want to make it easier for people to get things done, better understand what they're looking at, and have easier access to more advanced results and insight to analyze the data they're being given, the connections it has across the web, and the connections it might have in the real world. And while it's great for someone in #roamcult to obsess about how neat their note-taking system is and how good their notes are, what about "],[0,[0],1,"first"],[0,[],0," obsessing over organizing the work that we do and how we understand it? Why not have software that focuses on organizing all of the content and meanings to content first? Then, we can take supplementary notes that not only connect to the same bi-directional links but add to the context that changed the search query or your internal thought process."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"When we search, there is a very non-linear process that we follow that is nowadays called digital berrypicking. With digital berrypicking, a user searches something, has a moment of input(they read something, digest, think about it, etc), and then either augment the search query or click a link that takes them down the rabbit hole. The user keeps doing this until they reach their result. However, along the way, they have moments of thought, which can influence what they click or how they augment the search query. Knowledge workers might log these moments of thought in their working notes in Roam, but, ultimately, the trail of berrypicking is lost. That trail provides valuable context that would be able to explain what factors went into a decision, the context of those factors, and so on."]]],[10,2],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Knowledge workers and members of #roamcult might argue that so-called "digital gardening" is more about learning and understanding contexts and that buying into this system assumes that you're willing to take the time for high output. Besides, it assumes that we should spend more time organizing our learning and our interpretation of events/facts than we should organize a collection of the source material, places/ways in which that source material was found, and new ways of interpreting it. Of course, building knowledge is important, and Roam has some great features for that, chiefly spaced repetition. However, multiple things need to be considered that further explain the importance(and benefits) of "connecting" the two, with more of an emphasis on work and understanding(eg. in a workspace/OS):"]]],[3,"ol",[[[0,[],0,"Building personal knowledge is great, but sharing that knowledge is just as(if not more) important. From a technical standpoint, being able to teach others what you learn is a testament to your newfound knowledge. But from a practical standpoint, we constantly share multimedia. We want to be able to quickly share information and its exact context, in the most exact and raw form possible. While a proper publishing format would need to be created to allow for data analysis and visualization, "connecting" work and the notes that contextualize it would centralize everything in a work session, making it easier to "pick and choose" different parts for export. What if we had a community-created Wikipedia where data was verified by researchers and that data could be proved by an AI who inspects their workspace for exact references that back up statements? Then the creative economy is back in the hands of the data, and statements are fully backed up with "],[0,[0],1,"human"],[0,[],0," logic."]],[[0,[],0,"With common workspaces, it's hard to focus. We get tons of notifications, have multiple windows open, have shorter attention spans, and deal with a suite of applications branded to have the same ordinary file structure, the same ordinary app architecture, and the same arbitrary ways of thinking about the user's needs. By emphasizing the organization of the actual work, the user can spend more time focusing on their work and trying to better understand it, as opposed to organizing their initial written reaction to it. Spend more time doing!"]],[[0,[],0,"Connecting the two helps us analyze hidden anomalies. They give us a larger piece of the puzzle."]]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"While it's great to use a tool that can help increase your thoughts and help you better catalog your learnings, it's equally as important to understand the context in which the work was done and the comment was made, and there's a lot of potential for this technology."]]],[1,"p",[]]]}
posts.html:
Knowledge management and tools for thought have become buzzworthy topics in the tech industry, notably with the rise of Roam Research, the note-taking tool for thought, and the concurrent rise of #roamcult on Twitter. Productivity and personal development have been topics of fascination by the most advanced technologists, yet the community of knowledge management and tools for thought enthusiasts never found a home nor a true voice until the rise of Roam. The community races to build extensions for Roam despite the lack of a public API, engages in lengthy Twitter threads with the product's founder and evangelist, Conor White-Sullivan, about the product's features, and shares organizational hacks. In the process, Conor has taught users about the efficacy of certain note-taking methods in Roam, with some yielding high output from users that need it the most(eg. those who deal with the most knowledge and have the most difficult time organizing it). As the community focuses mostly on the upkeep involved in organizing a Roam graph or a Notion page, I offer a glimpse into the future of thought work. What if we managed work activity in the same way we so finely maintain our Roam graphs?

For those who might not be familiar, here's how Roam works in a nutshell: Roam is a note-taking app that helps users organize and contextualize knowledge. Users create bidirectional links for each named entity("real world" objects, such as places, people, ideas, or events) in their notes, so they can see every reference to a named entity, as well as the context within which it was referenced. Roam features a toolbelt of advanced commands to manipulate text the same way a statistician would master functions in Microsoft Excel. For example, a user can filter specific references to a named entity, embed code blocks and images into notes, embed references to text snippets between different notes, and even learn notes with spaced repetition.

Users who become fully invested in organizing their knowledge and spend lots of time working with loads of data tend to get the most out of Roam. In particular, the Zettlekasten note-taking method has been popularized by #roamcult, which emphasizes constant note-taking to enlarge the number of connections between concepts and help one build knowledge. This system requires a lot of hands-on work but has helped many, especially knowledge workers, organize their work. It has also emphasized writing as an important part of the creative process for any discipline, especially product design, one that is so subjective.

While a tool for thought(namely Roam) helps produce a rich graph of contextualized notes and(if properly followed) can help users produce better ideas/learn more, notes generally aren't the only part of a user's workflow, even if the user is a knowledge worker, simply because of how many steps and applications typical workflows require. Even if a knowledge worker's only other app interaction is searching Google, a database, or a website, a knowledge worker still makes multiple decisions and inquiries that lead them to either augment the search query, read a particular website/data entry/article, or click a link. This non-linear search process called berrypicking is one that most people follow as they search the web, but is one that is highly utilized by knowledge workers, who surface multiple sources, search results, and webpages to collect the context necessary to augment the search query, find the right results, or come to certain conclusions/form certain hypotheses.

And yes, it's important to focus on the learning process and understanding that the knowledge worker must make their interpretations of the information they are presented. However, a knowledge worker could be much more productive and make better use of contextualized information if they had a language to organize the rest of their workflow with the same degree of specificity and the same access to context as in Roam. Other professions have advanced tools that they use to do their work and track their progress(insert examples), so why can't knowledge workers?

Here are a few examples of tools that can be crafted for creatives to help them experience the quantum leaps in their productivity, creativity, and cognition as they work, the same way Roam has for knowledge workers:

  1. An advanced editing tool for interface and interaction designers

Other creative disciplines have advanced software they can use. Knowledge workers can use Roam, a software engineer can use an IDE, a video editor can use advanced editing software, a music producer can use a DAW, the list goes on and on. All of these tools have steep learning curves but offer rich languages for building creative material and, over time, creatives experience exponential increases in their productivity, just as one sees exponential increases in memory as they expand their Roam graph and their usage of the spaced repetition system. Interface designers, however, are stuck to vector-based software programs, such as Figma, Sketch, and Adobe Illustrator/Photoshop/XD. While these programs are easy to use and allow designers to streamline certain parts of their workflow, motion design features are limited, as are design system features, which seem too primitive and assume that a feature has to be implemented a certain way regardless of the context, which doesn't offer much room for exploration. Some tools, such as Framer and Facebook Origami, attempt to create languages to prototype interactions or further customize interface designs, but overall, designers are stuck using primitive vector-based systems that enforce a very "static" style of design and make it harder to use design software as a legitimate tool in a project or its tech stack, or just help the designer best express themself.

2. Online databases and berrypicking

A knowledge worker might spend a lot of time in Roam and Notion organizing their notes and trying to learn it, but for anyone who is working with content, or in some other way, there is other work and thinking done outside of Roam that users can't properly organize or record. Take the way people search, for example. When search engines like Google first became popular twenty years ago, most users would follow classic information retrieval models that were set by the search engines, where a user would search for something, click on their result, do what they have to do, and then close their browser or move on to the next task. Nowadays, most people who search the web, especially creatives and tech geeks, follow an information retrieval pattern called berrypicking(insert Focus image),  where researchers make certain discoveries or inquiries as they search(or browse a database) which they then use to augment the query, change their notes, do something in their work software, etc. It's these moments that contain the true source of our inspiration and provides the real context.

For the past three years, I have been researching knowledge management, mostly within the frame of desktop organization and productivity in the workflow of many SaaS apps. I want to make it easier for people to get things done, better understand what they're looking at, and have easier access to more advanced results and insight to analyze the data they're being given, the connections it has across the web, and the connections it might have in the real world. And while it's great for someone in #roamcult to obsess about how neat their note-taking system is and how good their notes are, what about first obsessing over organizing the work that we do and how we understand it? Why not have software that focuses on organizing all of the content and meanings to content first? Then, we can take supplementary notes that not only connect to the same bi-directional links but add to the context that changed the search query or your internal thought process.

When we search, there is a very non-linear process that we follow that is nowadays called digital berrypicking. With digital berrypicking, a user searches something, has a moment of input(they read something, digest, think about it, etc), and then either augment the search query or click a link that takes them down the rabbit hole. The user keeps doing this until they reach their result. However, along the way, they have moments of thought, which can influence what they click or how they augment the search query. Knowledge workers might log these moments of thought in their working notes in Roam, but, ultimately, the trail of berrypicking is lost. That trail provides valuable context that would be able to explain what factors went into a decision, the context of those factors, and so on.

Knowledge workers and members of #roamcult might argue that so-called "digital gardening" is more about learning and understanding contexts and that buying into this system assumes that you're willing to take the time for high output. Besides, it assumes that we should spend more time organizing our learning and our interpretation of events/facts than we should organize a collection of the source material, places/ways in which that source material was found, and new ways of interpreting it. Of course, building knowledge is important, and Roam has some great features for that, chiefly spaced repetition. However, multiple things need to be considered that further explain the importance(and benefits) of "connecting" the two, with more of an emphasis on work and understanding(eg. in a workspace/OS):

  1. Building personal knowledge is great, but sharing that knowledge is just as(if not more) important. From a technical standpoint, being able to teach others what you learn is a testament to your newfound knowledge. But from a practical standpoint, we constantly share multimedia. We want to be able to quickly share information and its exact context, in the most exact and raw form possible. While a proper publishing format would need to be created to allow for data analysis and visualization, "connecting" work and the notes that contextualize it would centralize everything in a work session, making it easier to "pick and choose" different parts for export. What if we had a community-created Wikipedia where data was verified by researchers and that data could be proved by an AI who inspects their workspace for exact references that back up statements? Then the creative economy is back in the hands of the data, and statements are fully backed up with human logic.
  2. With common workspaces, it's hard to focus. We get tons of notifications, have multiple windows open, have shorter attention spans, and deal with a suite of applications branded to have the same ordinary file structure, the same ordinary app architecture, and the same arbitrary ways of thinking about the user's needs. By emphasizing the organization of the actual work, the user can spend more time focusing on their work and trying to better understand it, as opposed to organizing their initial written reaction to it. Spend more time doing!
  3. Connecting the two helps us analyze hidden anomalies. They give us a larger piece of the puzzle.

While it's great to use a tool that can help increase your thoughts and help you better catalog your learnings, it's equally as important to understand the context in which the work was done and the comment was made, and there's a lot of potential for this technology.
posts.plaintext:
Knowledge management and tools for thought have become buzzworthy topics in the
tech industry, notably with the rise of Roam Research, the note-taking tool for
thought, and the concurrent rise of #roamcult on Twitter. Productivity and
personal development have been topics of fascination by the most advanced
technologists, yet the community of knowledge management and tools for thought
enthusiasts never found a home nor a true voice until the rise of Roam. The
community races to build extensions for Roam despite the lack of a public API,
engages in lengthy Twitter threads with the product's founder and evangelist,
Conor White-Sullivan, about the product's features, and shares organizational
hacks. In the process, Conor has taught users about the efficacy of certain
note-taking methods in Roam, with some yielding high output from users that need
it the most(eg. those who deal with the most knowledge and have the most
difficult time organizing it). As the community focuses mostly on the upkeep
involved in organizing a Roam graph or a Notion page, I offer a glimpse into the
future of thought work. What if we managed work activity in the same way we so
finely maintain our Roam graphs?

For those who might not be familiar, here's how Roam works in a nutshell: Roam
is a note-taking app that helps users organize and contextualize knowledge.
Users create bidirectional links for each named entity("real world" objects,
such as places, people, ideas, or events) in their notes, so they can see every
reference to a named entity, as well as the context within which it was
referenced. Roam features a toolbelt of advanced commands to manipulate text the
same way a statistician would master functions in Microsoft Excel. For example,
a user can filter specific references to a named entity, embed code blocks and
images into notes, embed references to text snippets between different notes,
and even learn notes with spaced repetition.

Users who become fully invested in organizing their knowledge and spend lots of
time working with loads of data tend to get the most out of Roam. In particular,
the Zettlekasten note-taking method has been popularized by #roamcult, which
emphasizes constant note-taking to enlarge the number of connections between
concepts and help one build knowledge. This system requires a lot of hands-on
work but has helped many, especially knowledge workers, organize their work. It
has also emphasized writing as an important part of the creative process for any
discipline, especially product design, one that is so subjective.

While a tool for thought(namely Roam) helps produce a rich graph of
contextualized notes and(if properly followed) can help users produce better
ideas/learn more, notes generally aren't the only part of a user's workflow,
even if the user is a knowledge worker, simply because of how many steps and
applications typical workflows require. Even if a knowledge worker's only other
app interaction is searching Google, a database, or a website, a knowledge
worker still makes multiple decisions and inquiries that lead them to either
augment the search query, read a particular website/data entry/article, or click
a link. This non-linear search process called berrypicking is one that most
people follow as they search the web, but is one that is highly utilized by
knowledge workers, who surface multiple sources, search results, and webpages to
collect the context necessary to augment the search query, find the right
results, or come to certain conclusions/form certain hypotheses.

And yes, it's important to focus on the learning process and understanding that
the knowledge worker must make their interpretations of the information they are
presented. However, a knowledge worker could be much more productive and make
better use of contextualized information if they had a language to organize the
rest of their workflow with the same degree of specificity and the same access
to context as in Roam. Other professions have advanced tools that they use to do
their work and track their progress(insert examples), so why can't knowledge
workers?

Here are a few examples of tools that can be crafted for creatives to help them
experience the quantum leaps in their productivity, creativity, and cognition as
they work, the same way Roam has for knowledge workers:

 1. An advanced editing tool for interface and interaction designers

Other creative disciplines have advanced software they can use. Knowledge
workers can use Roam, a software engineer can use an IDE, a video editor can use
advanced editing software, a music producer can use a DAW, the list goes on and
on. All of these tools have steep learning curves but offer rich languages for
building creative material and, over time, creatives experience exponential
increases in their productivity, just as one sees exponential increases in
memory as they expand their Roam graph and their usage of the spaced repetition
system. Interface designers, however, are stuck to vector-based software
programs, such as Figma, Sketch, and Adobe Illustrator/Photoshop/XD. While these
programs are easy to use and allow designers to streamline certain parts of
their workflow, motion design features are limited, as are design system
features, which seem too primitive and assume that a feature has to be
implemented a certain way regardless of the context, which doesn't offer much
room for exploration. Some tools, such as Framer and Facebook Origami, attempt
to create languages to prototype interactions or further customize interface
designs, but overall, designers are stuck using primitive vector-based systems
that enforce a very "static" style of design and make it harder to use design
software as a legitimate tool in a project or its tech stack, or just help the
designer best express themself.

hand???

the sheer lack of imagination in design tooling astounds me

databases and berrypicking

A knowledge worker might spend a lot of time in Roam and Notion organizing their
notes and trying to learn it, but for anyone who is working with content, or in
some other way, there is other work and thinking done outside of Roam that users
can't properly organize or record. Take the way people search, for example. When
search engines like Google first became popular twenty years ago, most users
would follow classic information retrieval models that were set by the search
engines, where a user would search for something, click on their result, do what
they have to do, and then close their browser or move on to the next task.
Nowadays, most people who search the web, especially creatives and tech geeks,
follow an information retrieval pattern called berrypicking(insert Focus image),
 where researchers make certain discoveries or inquiries as they search(or
browse a database) which they then use to augment the query, change their notes,
do something in their work software, etc. It's these moments that contain the
true source of our inspiration and provides the real context.

[https://twitter.com/Dylan_Steck/status/1342197974328340486?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw]
Imagine Wikipedia as a graph of Linked Data!For the past three years, I have
been researching knowledge management, mostly within the frame of desktop
organization and productivity in the workflow of many SaaS apps. I want to make

data they're being given, the connections it has across the web, and the
connections it might have in the real world. And while it's great for someone in
#roamcult to obsess about how neat their note-taking system is and how good
their notes are, what about first obsessing over organizing the work that we do
and how we understand it? Why not have software that focuses on organizing all

context that changed the search query or your internal thought process.

When we search, there is a very non-linear process that we follow that is
nowadays called digital berrypicking. With digital berrypicking, a user searches
something, has a moment of input(they read something, digest, think about it,
etc), and then either augment the search query or click a link that takes them
down the rabbit hole. The user keeps doing this until they reach their result.
However, along the way, they have moments of thought, which can influence what
they click or how they augment the search query. Knowledge workers might log
these moments of thought in their working notes in Roam, but, ultimately, the

[https://medium.com/free-code-camp/browserhistory-2abad38022b1#.5aezub8z2])
Knowledge workers and members of #roamcult might argue that so-called "digital
gardening" is more about learning and understanding contexts and that buying
into this system assumes that you're willing to take the time for high output.
Besides, it assumes that we should spend more time organizing our learning and
our interpretation of events/facts than we should organize a collection of the
source material, places/ways in which that source material was found, and new
ways of interpreting it. Of course, building knowledge is important, and Roam
has some great features for that, chiefly spaced repetition. However, multiple
things need to be considered that further explain the importance(and benefits)
of "connecting" the two, with more of an emphasis on work and understanding(eg.
in a workspace/OS):

 1. Building personal knowledge is great, but sharing that knowledge is just
    as(if not more) important. From a technical standpoint, being able to teach
    others what you learn is a testament to your newfound knowledge. But from a
    practical standpoint, we constantly share multimedia. We want to be able to
    quickly share information and its exact context, in the most exact and raw
    form possible. While a proper publishing format would need to be created to
    allow for data analysis and visualization, "connecting" work and the notes
    that contextualize it would centralize everything in a work session, making
    it easier to "pick and choose" different parts for export. What if we had a
    community-created Wikipedia where data was verified by researchers and that
    data could be proved by an AI who inspects their workspace for exact
    references that back up statements? Then the creative economy is back in the
    hands of the data, and statements are fully backed up with human logic.
 2. With common workspaces, it's hard to focus. We get tons of notifications,
    have multiple windows open, have shorter attention spans, and deal with a
    suite of applications branded to have the same ordinary file structure, the
    same ordinary app architecture, and the same arbitrary ways of thinking
    about the user's needs. By emphasizing the organization of the actual work,
    the user can spend more time focusing on their work and trying to better
    understand it, as opposed to organizing their initial written reaction to
    it. Spend more time doing!
 3. Connecting the two helps us analyze hidden anomalies. They give us a larger
    piece of the puzzle.

While it's great to use a tool that can help increase your thoughts and help you
better catalog your learnings, it's equally as important to understand the
context in which the work was done and the comment was made, and there's a lot
of potential for this technology.

users.name: Dylan Steck
users.bio: Interface design and development. Humane technology advocate. Building the future of knowledge management at Stecknologies.
